7371474756039626030.voice_to_text: It’s also too hot for planes. Yes, that is a thing we have to deal with. And today we learned of another new thing we have to worry about: Life-threatening air turbulence. Today, one person passed away and several were injured when a Singapore Airlines flight hit a really bad air pocket on a trip from London to Singapore. Such incidents are rare, but clear air turbulence, which is when out of nowhere in the clear blue sky your plane suddenly starts acting like a mechanical bull, is on the rise. One recent study found that it had increased 50% over the North Atlantic in the past 40 years. Could climate change be to blame? Possibly. It could be making the jet stream more unstable. But the important thing to know is that this is a risk and that there is a simple solution for dealing with it. Just keep your seatbelt fastened even when the fastened seatbelt light isn't lit.

7367510913408126250.voice_to_text: so I am stitching this specific clip from The Ocean Cleanup because I think it really hinges into a lot of my world view but also I just love the work that they do and I think it's really helpful account to follow um if you're someone who is like following all the different climate crises happening at the same time I like hear that saying all the time “look for the helpers” and I think this account is a really good example of helpers like the people who are out there and actively doing things to undo some of the horrible things that humans have done to this planet but on a more broad sense like I also was having a conversation with a friend this past week about like nihilism and about the sort of arc of freedom in this country and the reactionary way that kind of both sides of our political divide react to all of those things um and how it sort of hinges into my own world view and I think we all know that quote that like the arc of humanity bends towards freedom (okay barely got that right*) but at the same time I also think it's sort of important to understand especially in a political sense um while we're on the precipice of this next election and there are plenty of people who are very rightfully not interested in either side of the divide to kind of have a broader conversation I think about the way in which that affects both our day to day lives and how things happen at a more macro level I just feel as though it really is a great breeding ground for apathy to fall into that sort of space of our slowly backsliding into fascism and we're no longer going to have democracy in this country and I know that I sit in a really privileged position as a white cis-male so I just want to like caveat that and obviously I can't speak to having not experienced a lot of the atrocities that like black and brown folks feel in this country um at most I can speak to the sort of LGBT struggle having live through part of that but at the worst of it being like fighting for marriage Equality which is nothing like fighting for our lives during the AIDS crisis which predates me and then I think a lot of the horrible things that like our trans Brethren are going through today and being systematically and legally eliminated in as many ways as possible but again sort of saying in a macro level the way I was talking about it with my friend was that the way this country tends to work is that at the pendulum swing we generally have two terms of a democratic president and then two terms of a Republican president and usually all of the progressive stuff that happens during that democratic presidency has a sort of backswing that happens in the following eight years that said I don't think that the pendulum just goes back and forth I do believe that while that pendulum sort of goes back and forth it also moves forward so every time we do have that pendulum swing I feel as though we make maybe small bits of ground up in that time and taking it to an even more broad like worldview sense I don't think that I'm someone who's like a super optimist I'm definitely a realist but at the same time there's a part of me that 7363999758949649707.voice_to_text: What does "native adjacent" mean? Andy's idea of "native adjacent" plants is an interesting one because it gets at this idea that what makes a native plant might not be so black and white. Over the last four months, I've been writing this paper about the usefulness of native plants as they face the problems posed by climate change. And in the paper I talk a lot about what the definition of a native plant is. The main factor we often talk about when defining what makes a plant native is geographical proximity. So is it native to your city, your county, your state, your country, your continent? How do you define what region is close enough to make that plant native? And while geographic proximity is useful, it has its limitations. Take for example, if I say that all plants within 10 km are native, well, I go 10 km to the top of the nearest mountain, are those plants really native to where I am here? Geographically maybe, but climatically, not really. While nativity maps are useful to an extent, they're not gonna show you the biomes or the habitats that these plants are native to. And if we add climate change into the mix, those biomes and habitats are currently changing and are going to continue changing into the future. So what does that mean for our definition of a native plant? A point that I make my paper is that, in this era of climate change, the definition of a native plant shouldn't just take into account geographic proximity or climactic conditions, but also the benefits that these plants have for native fauna. Because if we're planting native plants solely based on their historical region of nativity, what good is it if they can't survive the climactic conditions of the future? They can't benefit the local fauna if they can't survive. This is an idea that I found in this research paper from the university of Lausanne that talks about tree planting as it relates to climate change. The paper is in French, but I will break it down for you because it's super interesting. The researchers used climate modeling to predict the climate in Lausanne in 2070 and then rated a list of 110 trees. These 110 trees from around the world were rated according to how well they would be adapted to this predicted future climate. Trees best adapted to the predicted climate received a score of one, and then the trees that were less and less adapted to that predicted climate received scores of 2, 3, or 4 being the worst. But the researchers didn't just stop at looking at the adaptability of these trees to the future climate; they also took into consideration the potential for supporting local biodiversity. Biodiversity potential was calculated mainly from two factors: geographic deviation and phylogenetic deviation. I'll explain what that means. We've already kind of discussed the geographic deviation — basically, the plants that are found in this area in this close region here in Switzerland are considered to have a low geographic deviation because they're from the area. Trees found on the European continent, but not necessarily in this local area, are considered to have a medium geographic deviation. And then trees found on another continent are considered to have a high geographic deviation. The idea is that the area that a tree is native to, the closer that is to here in Switzerland, the more likely that that tree would be able to support the local wildlife. So a tree from Italy is probably more likely to support wildlife here in Switzerland than a tree from Japan. The second factor that the researchers taken to account for this biodiversity potential is the phylogenetic deviation. Phylogenetic is talking about genes, DNA, how closely things are related. So we're talking about family. The closer two plants are related, the less phylogenetic deviation there is. So if we take maple trees as an example, maybe we already have a species of maple tree here in Switzerland, and we're considering planting a species of maple tree that comes from Japan. Geographically speaking, that's a long ways off. But genetically speaking, that maple tree is a cousin. So the wildlife here might still be able to take advantage of that Japanese maple tree because they're genetically related. They're family, they're cousins. The closer these two plants are related, the less phylogenetic deviation there is, the more biodiversity potential there is. And these are all important things to consider because, as the researchers point out, some of the trees that are the best adapted for this future 2070 climate, they don't have very much biodiversity potential. However, some of the trees down here in the second place category, even though they may not be the best adapted to the future climate, they do have a pretty good biodiversity potential. This is why, in these conversations around planting native plants, I think it's really important to consider some of these native adjacents, as Andy calls them, because what might be native adjacent today could be the perfect native plant tomorrow.

The Bill, effective July 1st, also prohibits offshore wind farms, of which there are none off Florida, by the way, favors natural gas, eliminates energy conservation programs, reduces gas pipeline regulations, and increases protections for gas appliances. Now, the governor says the Bill, and I quote here, is restoring sanity in our approach to energy. End quote. Now, critics say it ignores the reality of threats the state faces and de emphasizes policies to help mitigate climate change. This comes as Florida faces challenges from rising sea levels, flooding, and an approaching Hurricane season that's forecast to be especially active.

7369287789030182190.voice_to_text: It’s the kind of heart-stopping  wildlife encounter sailors dread. Killer whales ramming boats, at times breaking the rudders leaving the boats unsteerable or worse, sinking them. And now it's happened again. The crew of the 50-foot Alberon Coñac sailboat calling for help early Sunday, a few miles from the Strait of Gibraltar  in Moroccan waters, saying orcas damaged the rudder  and the yacht was taking on water. The crew rescued, the boat sank. The same pod of orcas have been toying with boats off the  Atlantic coast of Spain, Portugal, and France since 2020. More than 400 encounters sinking  at least five boats. This particular pod is critically endangered and scientists say returns to the same  area every year looking for bluefin tuna. Marine conservation group  Ocean Care stressing “We do not believe that the orcas’  behaviour is any form of revenge or a deliberate attack on people.” Experts think the orcas may actually be  teaching each other how to break boat rudders. Spanish Maritime Rescue now telling sailors to steer clear of the area  from April to August, stay close to the coast,  and don't try to harm the animals.
7369287789030182190.video_description: A pod of orcas sunk a yacht a few miles from the Strait of Gibraltar early Sunday. THe same pod of orcas has been toying with boats since 2020. #TODAYShow #Orcas

7264249421032885550.video_description: If you think air travel couldn’t possibly get more miserable, #climatechange is here to prove you wrong ✈️☀️ #Airplanes have less lift when the mercury rises, making it harder to take off and adding to flight delays and other disruptions, says Mark Gongloff. It’s literally getting too hot for planes. #Airlines and #pilots will often choose to delay #flights or unload passengers and luggage to shed weight from planes when the temperature climbs too high. This leads to cascading schedule disruptions across the entire system, along with passengers occasionally being trapped for hours on runways inside roasting aircraft. #pilottok #airplanetiktok #skytok #climatecrisis #flightdelay #climatetok
7264249421032885550.voice_to_text: It's too hot for humans lately, but it's also too hot for planes. Yes, that is a thing we have to deal with now, and here's why. Plane might seem to stay in the air because of magic, but it's really just science. Air moves around a plane's wings and gives it lift. When the air is hot, its molecules move much faster. This makes the air less dense, and that means planes have a lot less lift, and it makes it harder for them to take off and stay in the air. So when it gets too hot, pilots and airlines have to make some hard choices. Maybe they toss passengers and luggage off the plane. Maybe they delay the flight until it gets cooler. Maybe they make you sit on the runway in a plane without air conditioning where you roast for hours. None of that is good. What it all adds up to is more delays. As if air travel needed more of those. Believe it or not, hot weather causes more flight delays than cold weather. And as the southern US experience for the past several weeks, global warming means the air just keeps getting hotter and hotter. Climate change was already making air travel worse by fueling more turbulence and extreme weather and changing the speed and direction of wind. Extreme heat is just another way. Will ruin your vacation. Will this be the thing that finally wakes more of us up to take action? And stop burning so much fossil fuel, I. Maybe we could even skip some plane trips. They're pretty awful these days anyway.
